Please go through https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-networkd/+/73039 and make sure we have addressed the comments that are applicable here.

Also any definitions, functions are added, please make sure they are being used.

Unused code shouldn't be there.

Please don't keep creating new changes. People have already invested time in reviewing this one. When you create a new one, your reviewers have to read through all of the code as if it is brand new. When you update an existing review, they can just review the changes from revision to revision. By creating a new one, you're putting additional work on your reviewers, who already are giving you a gift of their time; don't waste it.
taken care

Do you need this ?
Yes, so I could use cout/cin directly without scope resolution std::

The guidelines for OpenBMC development is to avoid hiding the 'std' namespace in the way.
The 'using' keyword is typically reserved for performing an alias on complex D-Bus data structures.
OpenBMC source uses the fully qualified names for 'std', 'boost', and others.
Please don't alias 'std' away.
Ok, remove it.
Can you move all this defines and enums and structs to header file
It is few lines, let us localize to this command cpp.

struct NCSICapabilitiesInfo_ {

} NCSICapabilitiesInfo;
this may not be required, it declare a variable of this structure.
Double check to see if `__attribute__ ((packed))` is needed.
So far I didn't see any portable issue avoiding this attribute.

struct NCSICapabilitiesResponse_{
}NCSICapabilitiesResponse;
same as above
variable declaration is not required
Can  all this  const char*  moved to a header file ?
let's localize to this file. It is not used for another command.

Instead of multiple cout, use single cout with <<

For eg

  cout<<"  capabilities_flags = "<<"0x"<<hex<<ntohl(capRcv->capabilitiesInfo.capabilitiesFlags)<<endl
      <<"  broadcast_packet_filter_capabilities = "<<"0x"<<hex<<ntohl(capRcv->capabilitiesInfo.broadcastPacketFilterCapabilities)<<endl
      <<"  multicast_packet_filter_capabilities = "<<"0x"<<hex<<ntohl(capRcv->capabilitiesInfo.multicastPacketFilterCapabilities)<<endl
      <<"  buffering_capabilities = "<<"0x"<<hex<<ntohl(capRcv->capabilitiesInfo.bufferingCapabilities)<<endl
      <<"  aen_control_support = "<<"0x"<<hex<<ntohl(capRcv->capabilitiesInfo.aenControlSupport)<<endl
      <<"  unicast_filter_cnt = "<<(UNICAST_FILTER_MASK(capRcv->capabilitiesInfo.filterCnt))<<endl
      <<"  multicast_filter_cnt = "<<(MULTICAST_FILTER_MASK(capRcv->capabilitiesInfo.filterCnt))<<endl
      <<"  mixed_filter_cnt = "<<(MIXED_FILTER_MASK(capRcv->capabilitiesInfo.filterCnt))<<endl
      <<"  vlan_filter_cnt = "<<(VLAN_FILTER_MASK(capRcv->capabilitiesInfo.filterCnt))<<endl
      <<"  channel_cnt = "<<capRcv->capabilitiesInfo.channelCnt<<endl
      <<"  vlan_mode_support = "<<capRcv->capabilitiesInfo.vlanModeSupport<<endl;

Refer https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-networkd/+/72698/24/src/ncsi_util.cpp#130

OpenBMC CI Build fails.

@Sunder, you need to run clang-format -i
OpenBMC CI build fails, run clang-format -i for the files where you get the issue before submitting.
@Sunder - Please click "done" and reply if you've resolved all of the outstanding comments.  There are still 5 marked unresolved.

There was a pending commit for the clang-18 upgrade.  When you ran clang-format manually you induced a lot of code changes in your commit that were unrelated.  I've rebased your commit manually for you to avoid this.
No C-style macros.  Please use `static constexpr` or enums or lambda functions where appropriate.
Done
nit: Typical style would be NCSIGetCapabilitiesInfo
Done
We should not be relying on C-struct-unpacking.  This is not portable or safe.
Done

As long as the structures aren't variable length, are designed with C representations in mind, the type is declared `__attribute__((packed))`, appropriate size checks are done, and endianness is handled (netlink is host-endian by default, so shouldn't be a problem), then this can be okay.

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/56761591/how-do-i-organize-members-in-a-struct-to-waste-the-least-space-on-alignment
Hi Andrew, This link has some good suggestion to follow with respect to padding and alignment. Inline to this guideline, I have structure aligned on 32bit boundary, but last three parameter to 16bit. I have not seen any issues so far testing with target. I am using "reinterpret_cast" cast from nla void* to NCSIgetCapabilitiesResponse structure.
